title: The terror of "it's not meta" HAS to stop
body:
I understand that there is a meta for a reason. It's nice to have some clarity that certain things will work, and when you expect certain roles to be in certain places, you have a better chance of putting together a decent, balanced team. However, there's a problem when a few limited combinations of champion, role, and position get so cemented that people freak out whenever something different appears; i.e. when someone tries to break the meta and the immediate reaction of their peers is to ASSUME that it won't work just because it's DIFFERENT. That is when we have a problem.

Now the context for this came when I decided to try Ashe mid (I like mid lane because it feels less stressful to me than bot lane), and almost every time I found a match, I would be either immediately kicked or everyone else would panic-leave (if it was team builder), or someone would dodge as soon as I called Ashe mid (in other queues). This makes it pretty clear to me that people are reacting to seeing something new without thinking about it ("Oh I haven't seen that before it's not meta it must not work bye-" *dodge*).

The few times I did find a team that would take me, I tended to do okay, especially in my more recent matches (9/1/5, 5/1/8, 12/5/3), but that's not the point. The point is that there are unfair standards being placed on things which are not accepted as "meta" compared to those that are accepted. No Ezreal bot lane has to call his scores in chat to avoid being kicked. No one questions a player who picks Darius top. But try bringing an ADC mid and by my count, ~95% of players will refuse to even TRY playing with you.

The problem isn't that there is a set of things which is believed to work. The problem is that everything outside of that set is assumed to not work, including the things people haven't even tried yet.

TL;DR Give people a chance to try new things. Don't be driven by fear.

He has amazing sustain and fair sustained damage which isn't good in the current meta where most top laners are bursty. He counters people who can't 100-0 him like Cho'gath, Gragas, Malphite, etc because he can heal his hp back so quickly. Against someone like Riven, Fiora, or Tryndamere he can barely scratch them for like 30% health before dying.

Even people who play meta champs who play poorly get chewed out for it. If they were going to have a bad game, it doesn't matter what role or champ they picked, they probably would have done poorly. In fact, Nami being a support wouldn't be the worst feeder, what with her abilities being built to work on less than optimal gold. The enemy snowballing from that feeding is another matter, but then that's just a thing you have to deal with in this game no matter who plays what where.

I've contemplated using APCs for bot lane instead of AD for a few reasons:

1. ADC are squishy and most of them lack burst or escape
2. Mages tend to have good wave clear, some kind of CC, and sometimes some form of escape
3. The main reason bot lane takes a support is to protect the early game vulnerability of ADCs, so an APC/Support lane could probably exploit that weakness. It's the same reason you generally don't take ADCs mid.
4. AP is much harder to itemize against, defensively, than AD is, so having and AD/Bruiser jungle and AP mages in mid and bot could actually be fairly hard to deal with.
5. The real reason, you bring an ADC at all is for sustained dps, which comes into fruition late game, and is usually used for taking objectives like Baron, Turrets, and Inhibs. With certain APCs and the correct build, you could probably achieve similar results without one.

I don't think there's an issue with trying new things. My friend and I do it all the time.

The issue comes when you try new things, and like my friend, you allow others to also be trying things that don't synergize with your idea at the same time in the same team. 
Like, he wants to go Yi+Jax bot. Solid plan, since both are strong and easy. It falls apart when he says, "since we're doing something non-meta, we'll accept the Taric top, Thresh mid, and Ahri jungle."
 I'd be fine with all those... separately, with the other four on the team being proven strong in their roles.

That, or a team that might work well together like an Anivia supporting a Gnar with Vayne top, Jarvan jungling, and Gangplank mid. If there's at least some reasonable argument for the entire team comp, it's fine. But when two people are dorking around, and they let things that clearly have no synergy into the group, it screws everyone.
